perturbation.original_text: A  Confidential  Information@  shall  mean  any  and  all information  that a Party may reasonably  expect to remain  confidential and not shared with the general public at any time or that information that is protected by law.
perturbation.changed_text: A  Confidential  Information shall  mean  information that is deemed confidential by the disclosing Party.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'any and all information that a Party may reasonably expect to remain confidential and not shared with the general public at any time or that information that is protected by law', the definition of Confidential Information becomes overly broad and subjective. This creates uncertainty because Section 2 refers to 'disclosure of Confidential Information'. The original definition provided specific context for what constitutes confidential information, while the changed definition leaves it entirely up to the disclosing party's discretion, potentially leading to disputes over what information is truly protected under the agreement.

By removing subsection 'g.  Return to a Party or  destroy,  as  requested  by a Party,  within fifteen (15) days of the  termination of this Agreement,  any  Confidential Information  provided  to such  Party and in its  possession  and retain no copies or back-up tapes;', and by leaving references to the clause, creates an internal contradiction. Specifically, subsection 'd' references the 'obligation to return or destroy the Confidential Information as provided under paragraph g of this Section 3', which no longer exists. This creates uncertainty because the procedure for returning or destroying confidential information is undefined, even though it is still referenced in other sections of the clause.

perturbation.original_text: The  respective  rights  and  obligations  of  Business Affiliate  and UDC under the  provisions  of  Sections  3(g)  [Responsibilities of the Parties] and 3(h)  [Responsibilities of the Parties] and 6 shall survive the termination of this Agreement indefinitely.
perturbation.changed_text: The  respective  rights  and  obligations  of  Business Affiliate  and UDC under the  provisions  of  Sections 3(h)  [Responsibilities of the Parties] and 6 shall survive the termination of this Agreement indefinitely.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to Section 3(g) in the 'Survival' clause, while simultaneously keeping Section 3(d), which references Section 3(g), an internal contradiction is created. Subsection d of Section 3 mandates employees, subcontractors, etc., agree to 'return or destroy the Confidential Information as provided under paragraph g of this Section 3'. Because Section 3(g) no longer survives termination of the agreement according to the amended survival clause (7a), it is unclear whether the subcontractors, etc., are still required to adhere to the requirements as stated in subsection d after the termination of the agreement, since the specified procedure (formerly) outlined in 3(g) no longer exists.
